fields.description:
_When in *Edit* mode and a cursor is flashing  inside the comment box_, switching from Commits or Diff tabs back to Overview using shortcut puts the comment on focus.

Hence if you hit the shortcut 2 or 3, the number will be included in front of whatever comment you had typed into the comment box stopping the flow of switching between tabs.
fields.summary: Switching from Commits or Diff tabs back to Overview using shortcut seems to have wrong focus when in edit mode

fields.description:
When a customer selected create branch in Jira, they will be forwarded to BitBucket to create the branch. The branch name is based on the Jira issue key. 

However this field is editable, which for some customers can produce problems or create a branch that is incorrectly named. 

A suggested improvement is to be able to make the field for the issue key read-only when the call is issued rom Jira.
fields.summary: Prevent editing of issue key when branching from a Jira request

fields.description:
Sometimes I get mentioned in PRs, I naturally receive an email about it, which turns out to be the only entry point to the PR.

Maybe I am unaware of a feature or smthg, but it would be nice to get access to such PRs the same way I access the "created" and "reviewing" ones.
fields.summary: As a developer I want to get back to PRs I've been mentioned in

fields.description:
When you mention something like hash of git commit in a comment of a pull request, it is converted to HTML link pointing to that commit.
In our case we have projects S* and M* with repository X inside them, M*/X is fork of S*/X. 
When we try to mention a commit in a pull-request in main repository (S*/X), it points to the commit inside the fork (M*/X).  

This can also affect the JIRA source tab (raised in BSERV-4164).  In cases where the commit exists in multiple repositories, Bitbucket Server will link to the repository with the lowest ID.
fields.summary: Hash link points to some fork instead of current repository

fields.description: When connecting a new mirror, it's possible that the setup form is open for some time (while other configuration is being worked out) before being submitted. This can lead to a form submission error due to the XSRF token timing out.
fields.summary: Smart Mirror setup screen can suffer from XSRF token timeouts

fields.description:
When performing comment drift, the system needs to run certain {{git diff}} operations. If the pull request in question is extremely large (whether due to modifying a huge number of files, or due to modifying a number of huge files), these diffs can timeout and trigger comment drift to fail. That results in comment drift stacking up, as well as additional system load due to repeated failures.

Timeout failures in comment drift are not _directly_ user-visible. They only appear in the logs. However, when comment drift is not completing successfully, users may see out-of-place comments in the diff because drift has not been processed.
fields.summary: Comment drift fails for pull requests with extremely large diffs

fields.description:
When repositories contain nonstandard refs, ref sync incorrectly classifies them as branches and fails when trying to synchronize them.

"Nonstandard" refs in this case means any ref that's not in a place where built-in {{git}} commands write refs. The "standard" refs are:
* {{/refs/heads/}} for branches
* {{/refs/notes/}} for notes
* {{/refs/tags/}} for tags

For example, {{/refs/pull}} and {{/refs/pull-requests}} are nonstandard refs. No built-in {{git}} command will ever create them on its own. Since ref sync assumes anything that isn't a note or a tag is a branch, when it synchronizes a nonstandard ref it tries to qualify them as branches to verify they were synchronized. That results in it trying to look up the refs as, e.g., {{/refs/heads/refs/pull-requests/...}}. Since there's no such branch, ref sync fails with an error like:

fields.description:
When a reviewer is added or removed from a pull request, please add the option (at the repo level) for that event to be documented as a comment in the PR timeline. 
Consider including the following: 
# Who added or removed whom
# Reason? (very optional)
# Notify the added/removed reviewers via normal BB user prefs
fields.summary: Add an activity to the pull request timeline when a reviewer is added or removed
Inbox extra reviewers z-index

fields.description:
h3. Summary

{{git diff}} doesn't support CR (^M) as a line ending. This is a Git limitation, and not something related to Bitbucket Server or Stash. This manifests in two ways:

* Files which _only_ contain CR line endings show as a single-line diff, but they are processed correctly
* Files with _mixed_ line endings (part of the file is LF, or CRLF, and part is CR) show unexpected results _and can fail processing entirely_

When a mixed-ending file fails diffs, it can cause cascading failures in other parts of the system. The most important of these is comment drift, but it can also cause user-visible errors when attempting to view commit or pull request diffs.

h3. Expected Results

Unexpected CR (^M) line endings in the output _shouldn't_ cause diff processing to fail..

h3. Actual Results

One example of a CR (^M) related failure appearing in {{atlassian-bitbucket.log}}:
{noformat:title=atlassian-bitbucket.log}
2016-02-13 18:03:51,028 DEBUG [drift:thread-1]  c.a.bitbucket.scm.BaseCommand Executed /usr/local/git/bin/git diff -C --color=never -U1
0 --dst-prefix=dst:// --src-prefix=src:// da4a5448b487f62ef520a400f17db84fc82eb1ec 521a0d8597944d79ad88f1c0230da962b37900c0 --
2016-02-13 18:03:51,035 ERROR [drift:thread-1]  c.a.s.i.p.c.d.DriftCommentUpdateProcessor 13108:352@27: Error calculating comment drift
(1 attempts).

 First: 13108:360@14 (004bf1e4586c5ba193847e23d387393dda043d80, cd4936b90d6daab2df118a360c219c0f4bec65ea) -> (004bf1e4586c5ba193847e23d387393dda043d80, 5018f411979ba93ed8bbfa0bd1a8a356b65865b1)
        Last: 13108:360@14 (004bf1e4586c5ba193847e23d387393dda043d80, bf5df9fbf301c2776715a1bda416909edcee31a7) -> (004bf1e4586c5ba193847e23d387393dda043d80, 7fedf1e8d3a169332891b5b5aea2ed34aa110a99)
com.atlassian.bitbucket.ServerException: An error occurred while executing an external process: Expected diff header, but found [@@ -4145,9 +4145,9 @@ l5^Mɷ^Ot]
        at com.atlassian.bitbucket.scm.git.command.GitCommandExitHandler.evaluateThrowable(GitCommandExitHandler.java:115) ~[na:na]
        at com.atlassian.bitbucket.scm.git.command.GitCommandExitHandler.onCancel(GitCommandExitHandler.java:49) ~[na:na]
        at com.atlassian.bitbucket.scm.BaseCommand.callExitHandler(BaseCommand.java:135) ~[bitbucket-spi-4.1.0.jar:na]
        at com.atlassian.bitbucket.scm.BaseCommand$CommandFuture.internalGet(BaseCommand.java:251) ~[bitbucket-spi-4.1.0.jar:na]
        at com.atlassian.bitbucket.scm.BaseCommand$CommandFuture.get(BaseCommand.java:220) ~[bitbucket-spi-4.1.0.jar:na]
        at com.atlassian.bitbucket.scm.BaseCommand.call(BaseCommand.java:75) ~[bitbucket-spi-4.1.0.jar:na]
        at com.atlassian.stash.internal.pull.comment.drift.DiffCommentDriftStrategy.calculateDrift(DiffCommentDriftStrategy.java:233) ~[bitbucket-service-impl-4.1.0.jar:na]
{noformat}

h3. Workaround

CR (^M) is not a valid line ending to Git. Files which use CR line endings should be converted to use either LF (Linux, Unix) or CRLF (Windows) line endings. Files which consistently use LF or CRLF endings will diff correctly and parse without issue.
fields.summary: Harden diff parsing for files with CR (^M) line endings that "git diff" does not support

fields.description:
Git commit messages should be written using the imperative mood.

http://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/
https://github.com/git/git/blob/bca181109d6f054d525c71a84963bbdc1f0c40bf/Documentation/SubmittingPatches#L112

When pull requests are merged by BitBucket, the message starts with 'Merged in".

Question on StackOverflow:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/30721903/is-merged-in-a-commit-message-created-by-bitbucket-or-git
fields.summary: Merge commit messages should use the imperative mood

fields.description: Now that bitbucket server has `GIT-LFS` support I'm wondering if you can implement support for binary releases of software similar to how it is implemented in github.  This would be a very useful feature.  I believe gitlab also has binary release support at this point as well.
fields.summary: Binary Releases support (similar to github)

fields.description:
To implement a table-column in a plugin, you must add a web-section and hook your web-panels to that section. We should document this pattern in developer documentation.

Further, we have our own internal table-column addon sections that can be misinterpreted as public API, when they are not meant to be. We should hide or rename this points to better indicate that they are not plugin points for 3rd party plugins to use.
fields.summary: Better documentation of table column plugin points and their usage.

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When Java is updated on Windows and the installation of the previous Java version is removed, the service won't start up again without manual intervention to fix it.

h3. Environment
* Bitbucket Server and Stash running as a Windows service 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install a Bitbucket instance
# Update to a newer Java version

h3. Expected Results
- Service should be able to point to a newer version automatically.

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the {{commons-daemon}} log file and the service fails to start:
{noformat}
[2016-02-13 23:18:05] [info]  [ 5920] Commons Daemon procrun (1.0.15.0 64-bit) started
[2016-02-13 23:18:05] [info]  [ 5920] Running 'AtlassianBitbucket' Service...
[2016-02-13 23:18:05] [info]  [ 5844] Starting service...
[2016-02-13 23:18:05] [error] [ 5844] Failed creating java c:\program files\java\jre1.8.0_65\bin\server\jvm.dll
[2016-02-13 23:18:05] [error] [ 5844] The system cannot find the path specified.
[2016-02-13 23:18:05] [error] [ 5844] ServiceStart returned 1
[2016-02-13 23:18:05] [error] [ 5844] The system cannot find the path specified.
[2016-02-13 23:18:05] [info]  [ 5920] Run service finished.
{noformat}
 
h3. Notes
It would be great if there was a solution that allowed the service to resolve which Java dll to use based on the environment {{JAVA_HOME}} beforehand.

h3.Workaround
{panel}
*Service Name*

If you don't know the exact name of your old Bitbucket Server service, you can find out what they are by following the steps below:
# Navigate to {{'Control Panel' > 'Administrative Tools' > 'Services'}}.
# The 'Services' window should appear.
# Right-click on the service you wish to find out the name of, and select 'Properties' from the popup menu.
# The 'Service name' should appear in the 'General' tab.
- Use this parameter as a substitute for {{<ServiceName here>}} on the command below.
{panel}

After you checked the service name:
- {{cd}} to the bin directory the Bitbucket Server Installation ({{<Bitbucket Server Installation dir>/bin}}).
- Run from there:
-- For versions of *Bitbucket Server 5.0+*:
--- {{bservmgr.exe //ES//<ServiceName goes here>}}
-- For versions *prior to Bitbucket Server 5.0+*:
--- {{tomcat8w //ES//<ServiceName here>}}
- Change the service
-- After inspecting the service window that was opened by the last command, you'll be able to identify that the JVM configured in it is pointing to the "old Java" {{dll}} (i.e {{c:\<old_java_path>\bin\server\jvm.dll}} whereas it should be pointing to new one {{c:\<new_java_path>\bin\server\jvm.dll}}. 
-- If you change the {{dll}} accordingly, this issue will be fixed.
fields.summary: Java update on Windows get Bitbucket Server or Stash services to fail

fields.description:
As a PR creator, the main reason I visit Bitbucket is to see what changes I need to make to my PR. I think tasks are a great way to achieve that but there are a number of problems which make tasks difficult to use.

It's frustrating for the PR creator to have to create tasks themselves based on comments on a PR. Even though it's relatively simple and the comment context is preserved, it's a strange back-and-forth between commenter and PR creator – I feel like it would make more sense for the commenter to create tasks and the PR creator consume them. However, after many PRs, I've never seen a commenter create a task. Ideally, task creation would be somewhat automated and seamless, much like mail clients suggest creating calendar events.
fields.summary: Simplify task creation for reviewers

fields.description:
If a branch is created containing double quotes in its name, Bitbucket Server will fail to display the context menu for the *Actions* button in the branch listing page. 

*Analysis*
* Branch named as *feature/Revert-"Information-Doc"-Module*
* No error is shown in Bitbucket's log.
* With Chrome's Developer Tools, I see it shows as the menu was opened:
!branch-quote1.png|thumbnail!
* There's an error in the Console though:
!branch-quote2.png|thumbnail!

*Git client*
I was able to reproduce this locally having a *git version 2.3.8 (Apple Git-58)* in Bitbucket Server, which allows to create the branch with double quotes in its name.
I observed a different behavior on Windows using *git version 2.6.1.windows.1*, for which this doesn't occur, as it's not possible to create the branch with double quotes in its name in the first place. 

*Steps to reproduce*
# Go to your repository screen in Bitbucket Server and click on *Create Branch*.
# Set the branch name to a name containing double quotes (as in the example used: *feature/Revert-"Information-Doc"-Module*) and proceed creating the branch.
# Go to the branches listing screen and try clicking on the *Actions* button - it won't open, thus no action can be done over this branch.
fields.summary: Action context menu not shown if branch contains double quotes in its name

fields.description:
Atlassian Team,

(I love bitbucket).

I'm new to Bitbucket Server administration, but am wondering if The repository actions: Clone URL provided could display the SSH port which is configured at the server level?  This would save us all sorts of "dummy" emails from users who have properly setup their SSH keys but who do not know that the default SSH port which Bitbucket is listening to SSH traffic over is 7999.  

We could (of course) implement port forwarding as your documentations suggests, but this seems unnecessary IF the above story were to be implemented.
fields.summary: Display Configured SSH Port in Clone URL

fields.description:
When a pull request is created in Stash, there is a ref in the format of {{refs/pull-requests/<number>/from}} which becomes available while the PR is open.

The process of how to do this was from these sources:
* http://blogs.atlassian.com/2014/08/how-to-fetch-pull-requests/
* http://mark.shropshires.net/blog/checking-out-pull-requests-stash-and-github

The method of how we do this is from the Atlassian blog post above:
{noformat}
# Example for a PR with number "239"
git fetch origin pull-requests/239/from:pr/239/from
git checkout pr/239/from
{noformat}

However, recently we have noticed that this ref occasionally takes upto 5 minutes to become available after the PR is created. When this happens our automated CI returns with an error like:
{{fatal: Couldn't find remote ref pull-requests/<number>/from}} (where <number> is the PR number)

A similar error occurs if we try to fetch the specific hash we know is in the pull request:
{{fatal: reference is not a tree: XXXXXX}} (where XXXXX is the specific hash)


If we wait up to 5 minutes when this happens, the refs of both formats above become available. We are hosting stash on a pretty big machine.

This issue is making CI difficult, as we block pull requests until the CI job is run and successful. Waiting around for 5 or more minutes before we can start any jobs gets in the way of engineers.
fields.summary: Fetch refs/pull-requests/<number>/from intermittently takes several minutes to become available

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When the customer upgrades from the Stash ver2.10.0 to Bitbucket Server ver4.3.0, the old added access key at project and repository levels are not allowed to be deleted by the admin and thrown following error:
{noformat}
This access key no longer exists or you no longer have administrative rights to delete it.
{noformat}
The access key still still exist/visible at both project/repository settings and in the database as well.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Begin with Stash ver2.10.0 with external database(MySQL).
 # Added a LDAP (users and group) into User directory.
 # Given the LDAP group access to the project.
 # Create and add an users key access to project/repository
 # Upgrade to Bitbucket Server ver4.3.0 (or higher - see Affected Versions)
 # Use an System admin account to delete the access key.

h3. Expected Result

Allow the System admin to delete the access key
h3. Actual Result

When the System Admin tried to delete the access key, the System admin was thrown error message {{This access key no longer exists or you no longer have administrative rights to delete it.}} and the key not able to delete from the UI.
h3. Workaround

If you have already upgraded an instance after Bitbucket Server 3.9, you can do a quick fix by removing the key from the database:

(!) Always back up your data before performing any modifications to the database. If possible, test any insert, update, or delete SQL commands on a staging server first.
 # Backup your instance using [Bitbukcet Server backup client guide|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/using-the-bitbucket-server-backup-client-776640064.html]
 # Stop Bitbucket Server
 # Execute the following SQL query, where {{<user_email@mail.com>}} is the label of the key you cannot remove from the user interface:
{code:sql}
DELETE FROM AO_FB71B4_SSH_PUBLIC_KEY WHERE LABEL = '<user_email@mail.com>';{code}

      4. Restart Bitbucket Server

Alternatively, if you have not upgraded yet from Bitbucket Server 3.9 and below, you can upgrade to Bitbucket Server 4.12 directly because the bug in -BSERV-9380- had been fixed thus, the labels will be correctly set and the problem wouldn't appear to begin with.
fields.summary: Can't delete project access key after upgrade from Stash to Bitbucket Server

fields.description:
Currently when you merge a pull request through the Stash web front-end, you do not have full control of the commit message. This leads to polluted commit logs on master.

In particular, my group would like to use the squash merge strategy and have clean commit messages once the pull request is accepted. The only way to work around this issue that I am aware of is outlined here:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/283338/pull-requests-squashed-commits-remote-merges?continue=https%3A%2F%2Fanswers.atlassian.com%2Fquestions%2F283338%2Fpull-requests-squashed-commits-remote-merges&application=acac

This behavior means that what should be a 1 click operation is turned into a more laborious and error prone process.

 !image-2016-02-04-10-29-27-684.png|thumbnail! 

Is this related to the known issue with Stash, where it rejects merges if the filenames are > 255 characters long?

If we upgrade to the latest version, will this fix the issue?

Is there some way to look at the log files that Stash is generating, so we can pinpoint exactly *why* the merge is failing?

You can contact me on shane.tolmie at man.com.

fields.description:
The suggestion is to retrieve the repository creation date in some function from the REST API.
This date can be currently seen in the database, in the table *AO_BD73C3_REPOSITORY_AUDIT*. The following query returns the creation date for a given repository in a given project:

{code:sql}
select ra.DATE from AO_BD73C3_REPOSITORY_AUDIT ra
join repository r on r.id = ra.repository_id
join project p on p.id = r.project_id
where ra.ACTION like 'RepositoryCreatedEvent'
and r.slug like '<repo_slug>'
and p.project_key like '<project_key>'
{code}

In the query above, replace *<repo_slug>* by the corresponding repository slug of the repository for which you want to check the creation date, and *<project_key>* by the project key under which this repository was created.
fields.summary: Ability to get repository creation date via REST API

This is a bug; you should be returning the toHash of the destination revision of the pull request.

----

All I really want to do is make a useable snapshot of pull request review comments stored in Stash. When they start to pile up to more than a few dozen, it becomes EXTREMELY difficult to track comments and make sure they have been addressed. It's even worse when the REST API doesn't work properly and I can't get around the built-in browsing features of Stash/BBserver

fields.description:
h3. Summary

In case the SSH server does not start up, the SSH field is blank in the clone dialog. 

This can be confirmed by running {{netstat}} on the Bitbucket Server mirror server and confirming that it is not listening port 7999.

h3. Environment
* Bitbucket Datacenter and a mirror instance. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set up a Bitbucket Server Data Center instance
# Set up a mirror
# Block the port 7999 from being reached in case you can't reproduce the SSH plugin failure on startup (i.e. BSERV-8345)

Alternatively, you might be able to block the SSH plugin from starting up by cat {{/dev/random}} to a file or {{/dev/null}} before starting BbS.

h3. Expected Results
A clear error message indicating that SSH is not working properly should be shown.

h3. Actual Results
We show an empty URL for SSH, instead. See image below:
 !ssh_mirror.png|thumbnail! 
 
h3.Workaround
If you're hitting this, probably your SSH server plugin is not starting for some reason. Please follow workarounds described on BSERV-8345 accordingly.

h3. Suggested fix

We discussed making the SSH plugin required and Johnsoning BbS if it fails to start up.
fields.summary: SSH field is blank in clone dialog when SSH plugin doesn't start on mirror

Please put this back in; we use it to unambiguously refer to a pull request (e.g. "Hey Bill, could you figure out what we need to close out PR#77 and PR#82?"), and getting to the pull request number is now inconvenient.

fields.description:
Commenting on "normal" modifications in a source file gives the comment a code snippet in the overview, with the source code at the time of commenting. Whenever this is updated in a pull request by later commits being pushed this is flagged as outdated, indicating that the current state of the code may not be as indicated by the comment. The source code "tagged" and embedded with the comment stays on the version it was when the comment was left.

If however you leave a comment when an entire file was added in the branch being pull requested the comment does not behave the same way.

If the file is altered in commits and those are pushed to the branch in the pull request, the code snippet embedded in the comment is automatically updated to the current head of the branch, with no outdated tag or notice whatsoever that the comment was left on a earlier revision of the source.

I'm attaching a screenshot of something that does not make any sense, as the comment has already been fixed. But in the overview this is impossible to know.

In the specific case attached, the first line (line 27) ended with "((uint32) 3)" at the time of comment, and at that time the comment made sense.
fields.summary: Pull Request comments on added files don't retain history on source being commented

h3. Notes
- *Cause for issue 1:*
The problem is down to the {{/dev/random}} device having insufficient entropy when Bitbucket Server is started and because this device blocks until sufficient entropy is attained in the system it blocks both the Tomcat start-up process and the SSH plugin start-up process.
- *Cause of issue 2:*
The presence of the following JAVA option will cause this to occur:
{{-Dsun.net.spi.nameservice.provider.1=dns,sun}}
- *Cause for issue 3:*
Potential high load on the server when Bitbucket is coming up. 

h3.Workaround
- *Issue 1:*
The best workaround is to specify the {{/dev/urandom}} device as the preferred egd or entropy gathering daemon. This is done by editing setenv.sh and adding {{-Djava.security.egd=file:/dev/./urandom}} to {{JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS}} and and restarting the Bitbucket Server service.
{code}
#
# Occasionally Atlassian Support may recommend that you set some specific JVM arguments.  You can use this variable
# below to do that.
#
JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS="-Djava.security.egd=file:/dev/./urandom"
{code}
{panel}
(i)
Please note that the dots and slashed in java.security.egd must be exactly as above (due to this Java not-quite-a-bug): https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-6202721

For a definitive solution, you should try to work out why your system has insufficient entropy at the point Stash is launched. This will probably be tightly coupled to what else is running on in your virtual machine before Bitbucket Server is started.
{panel}
 
- *Issue 2:*
Remove the {{-Dsun.net.spi.nameservice.provider.1=dns,sun}} option from your JVM and restart the Bitbucket  Server service.

- *Issue 3:*
# Shut Bitbucket Server down.
# Remove the following directories. They will be rebuilt when Bitbucket Server starts again.
{noformat}
$BITBUCKET_HOME/plugins/.bundled-plugins/
$BITBUCKET_HOME/plugins/.osgi-cache/
{noformat}
# From the database, remove any required plugins from the plugin-state table (see https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BSERV-4290 for more information).
## Restart Bitbucket Server.
## Upon starting up, Bitbucket Server will re-extract the required plugins from {{<Bitbucket Server installation directory>/atlassian-bitbucket/WEB-INF/classes/bundled-plugins.zip}} and rebuild those plugin directories.

*PS:* after fixing this, Bitbucket server won't come up if the SSH server fails to start. The following message is shown on the UI:
{panel}
*A fatal error has occurred*

The following problem occurred, which prevents Atlassian Bitbucket from starting:
Required plugin com.atlassian.stash.ssh-plugin has failed to start

{panel}
fields.summary: Bitbucket Server should not start if the SSH plugin doesn't load

fields.description:
In our company we host different projects on Bitbucket Server for different customers where also some customers work with us together.
Sadly some project administrators use the "default permission" setting and unwisely make their project repository at least visible (and worst writeable) for every other stash users - thus partly also other customers...
This leads us to a lot of security concerns and we have to fix upo the project setup and reset the "default permission" setting. 
Current Workaround: We run scripts that check every few minutes if there is at least one project having another "defeult permission" setting than "none" and reset and warn the IT-Security team.

I'd like to ask a feature property setting like feature.public.access=false
(maybe: feature.default.permission=false or feature.default-permission=none,fixed)
fields.summary: Add Config Property to disable "default permission" project setting

fields.description:
Visual Studio 2015 currently only supports https or http transport.  Thus, a repo must use http/https when the Team Explorer in visual studio is used to interact with a bitbucket repo.

When a bitbucket server has SSH enabled, the 'Checkout with Sourcetree' option always attempts to use ssh which then fails to find the existing repo in the Sourcetree URL action handler.  

It would be nice if the Sourcetree url handler was somehow provided both available URLs by bitbucket and it could then choose the appropriate one given it's known repos.  Lacking that, perhaps a per-project or per-user configuration that specified the preferred url scheme for sourcetree actions initiated from bitbucket.

Lack of this feature makes it hard for me to argue to visual studio users to migrate to sourcetree/bitbucket as once they configure visual studio to work these bitbucket actions are broke.
fields.summary: Support https protocol for 'checkout in sourcetree' for visual studio compatibility

fields.description:
When viewing a pull request diff consisting of a bunch of commits, I'd love to see the individual commit message (newest only?) on a mouseover of the changed line in the diff. If that's too obtrusive, then perhaps having a location to the left where you can mouseover and get the last commit that changed that line (basically a blame for the PR).

Intended goal:
A quick tooltip would provide context on the individual changes of a PR with a bunch of commits.
fields.summary: Show individual commit messages for PR diffs

The types of notification available are list here: https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/notifications-776639933.html#Notifications-Pullrequestnotifications

I want to be able to set whether each type of notification is sent:

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Creating a project with a "~username" and then creating a user with "username" will result in a 500 error when viewing the profile of that user. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a project named "~james" with a project key of "JAMES"
# Create a new user named "james"

h3. Expected Results

We should not allow the "~" character at the beginning of a project name. 

h3. Actual Results

{noformat}
2016-01-20 10:18:02,109 WARN  [http-nio-7990-exec-10] JAMES @1I94O6Lx618x967x0 1hz48zg 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 "GET /profile HTTP/1.1" o.h.e.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper SQL Error: 1062, SQLState: 23000
2016-01-20 10:18:02,109 ERROR [http-nio-7990-exec-10] JAMES @1I94O6Lx618x967x0 1hz48zg 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 "GET /profile HTTP/1.1" o.h.e.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper Duplicate entry '~james' for key 'uk_project_name'
2016-01-20 10:18:02,112 ERROR [http-nio-7990-exec-10] JAMES @1I94O6Lx618x967x0 1hz48zg 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 "GET /profile HTTP/1.1" o.h.e.j.batch.internal.BatchingBatch HHH000315: Exception executing batch [could not execute batch]
2016-01-20 10:18:02,133 ERROR [http-nio-7990-exec-10] JAMES @1I94O6Lx618x967x0 1hz48zg 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 "GET /profile HTTP/1.1" c.a.s.i.w.HandlerExceptionResolverImpl A database error has occurred.
com.atlassian.bitbucket.DataStoreException: A database error has occurred.
Caused by: org.springframework.dao.DataIntegrityViolationException: could not execute batch; SQL [insert into project (description, project_key, name, project_type, id) values (?, ?, ?, ?, ?)]; constraint [uk_project_name]; nested exception is org.hibernate.exception.ConstraintViolationException: could not execute batch
	at org.springframework.orm.hibernate4.SessionFactoryUtils.convertHibernateAccessException(SessionFactoryUtils.java:163) ~[spring-orm-
Caused by: org.hibernate.exception.ConstraintViolationException: could not execute batch
Caused by: java.sql.BatchUpdateException: Duplicate entry '~james' for key 'uk_project_name'
Caused by: com.mysql.jdbc.exceptions.jdbc4.MySQLIntegrityConstraintViolationException: Duplicate entry '~james' for key 'uk_project_name'
{noformat}

h3.Workaround

Change the "name" entry of "~james" in the "project" table to something like "JAMES".
fields.summary: 500 error viewing user profile with same name as project

h3. Environment
* Any release Stash or Bitbucket Server 4.0
* Running on Oracle database

h3. Steps to Reproduce

This is caused if running the upgrade according to the upgrade guide:
- [Bitbucket Server upgrade guide|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-upgrade-guide-776640551.html]

h3. Expected Results
Upgrade should finish successfully.

h3. Actual Results

	at org.eclipse.gemini.blueprint.service.importer.support.LocalBundleContextAdvice.invoke(LocalBundleContextAdvice.java:57) [gemini-blueprint-core-2.0.0.BUILD-atlassian-m002.jar:2.0.0.BUILD-atlassian-m002]
	at com.atlassian.activeobjects.internal.AbstractActiveObjectsFactory.create(AbstractActiveObjectsFactory.java:72) [activeobjects-plugin-1.1.5.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.activeobjects.internal.DelegatingActiveObjectsFactory.create(DelegatingActiveObjectsFactory.java:32) [activeobjects-plugin-1.1.5.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.activeobjects.osgi.TenantAwareActiveObjects$1$1$1.call(TenantAwareActiveObjects.java:91) [activeobjects-plugin-1.1.5.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.activeobjects.osgi.TenantAwareActiveObjects$1$1$1.call(TenantAwareActiveObjects.java:86) [activeobjects-plugin-1.1.5.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.sal.core.executor.ThreadLocalDelegateCallable.call(ThreadLocalDelegateCallable.java:38) [sal-core-3.0.5.jar:na]
	at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:266) [na:1.8.0_45]
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1142) [na:1.8.0_45]
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745) [na:1.8.0_45]
	... 47 frames trimmed
{noformat}
 
h3. Notes

ActiveObjects has a bug where if entity column getters are annotated with @Indexed and either @PrimaryKey or @Unique under Oracle it will try to create the additional index (for @Indexed) even though Oracle will have already created indexes for the primary key and unique columns when the table is created. Oracle allows only one index per column. This causes the mirroring plugin to fail to start due to errors from Oracle during migration and unfortunately causes the application to enter an unstable state. The logs will report: "java.sql.SQLException: ORA-01408: such column list already indexed"

The fix is to remove the redundant @Indexed annotations from the offending classes.

h3. Solution

Upgrade to Bitbucket Server 4.2.2, Bitbucket Server 4.3.1, or higher.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
It is difficult to understand from [a CAC page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/git-large-file-storage-794364846.html] if SSL configuration is one of the REQUIREMENTs for using Git LFS on Bitbucket Server.

The CAC page said
{quote}
SSL should be configured and the Base URL should be configured to a "https" URL. While Git LFS does support SSH remotes, the actual download & upload of LFS objects is via HTTP(S).
{quote}

It sounds like SSL configuration is one of the *REQUIREMENTs* for using Git LFS on Bitbucket Server.
However, we can use Git LFS on Bitbucket Server without any SSL configuration (use HTTP instead of HTTPS) and there are also such use cases.
e.g. Use Bitbucket Server only in a secure intranet and there is no anxiety about the security problem.

That's why I want to suggest that [the CAC page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/git-large-file-storage-794364846.html] should be updated to indicate SSL configuration is not a REQUIREMENT but a HIGHLY RECOMMENDED condition.
fields.summary: It is difficult to understand from a CAC page if SSL configuration is one of the REQUIREMENTs for using Git LFS on Bitbucket Server

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If we installed a vanilla Bitbucket Server 4.3.0, *AO_6978BB_RESTRICTED_REF* was created on the database and the max length of *REF_VALUE* column was set to *255*.
On the other hand, if we upgrade to Bitbucket Server 4.3.0 from 3.6.1, the same table was upgraded but the max length of *REF_VALUE* column was set to *450*.

h3. Environment
* OS : Linux (I used Ubuntu to reproduce this problem)
* DB : PostgreSQL (I used version 9.3 to reproduce this problem)
* Product
** Before upgrading: Stash 3.6.1
** After upgrading: Bitbucket Server 4.3.0 (4.1.0)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install vanilla Stash 3.6.1
# Integrate the instance with PostgreSQL
# Upgrade the instance to Bitbucket Server 4.3.0
# Check the definition of *AO_6978BB_RESTRICTED_REF* table

h3. Expected Results
After the upgrading from 3.6.1, the max length of *REF_VALUE* column should be set to *255*.

h3. Actual Results
After the upgrading from 3.6.1, the max length of *REF_VALUE* column is set to *450*.
 
h3.Workaround
Dropping the {{AO_6978BB_RESTRICTED_REF}} table is the only workaround.

# Stop Bitbucket Server
# Create a backup of the database (Especially the {{AO_6978BB_RESTRICTED_REF}} and {{AO_6978BB_PERMITTED_ENTITY}} tables which will be dropped)
# Drop the following tables, sequences, and indexes (these are from a PostgreSQL database, so the names may differ slightly)
## Tables
*** {{AO_6978BB_RESTRICTED_REF}}
*** {{AO_6978BB_PERMITTED_ENTITY}}
## Sequences
*** {{AO_6978BB_PERMITTED_ENTITY_ENTITY_ID_seq}}
*** {{AO_6978BB_RESTRICTED_REF_REF_ID_seq}}
## Indexes
*** {{index_ao_6978bb_res2050912801}}
*** {{index_ao_6978bb_res250715305}}
*** {{index_ao_6978bb_res847341420}}
*** {{index_ao_6978bb_per1013425949}}
# Start Bitbucket Server (The table will be automatically created again)
fields.summary: AO_6978BB_RESTRICTED_REF table wasn't upgraded correctly on PostgreSQL from Stash 3.6 to Bitbucket Server 4.1.0

fields.description:
PostgreSQL 9.5 is now available:

https://wiki.postgresql.org/wiki/What's_new_in_PostgreSQL_9.5

It has scalability and performance enhancements which should make it desirable to use with larger Bitbucket instances.

Please start the process for adding support for PostgreSQL 9.5 to Bitbucket Server.

I have it installed on a personal instance, and other than the red warning that Bitbucket Server puts on the top of the screen, I haven't noticed any failures or problems. I expect few changes to be required, and this is more a matter of the support and testing infrastructure requirements.
fields.summary: Support for PostgreSQL 9.5

fields.description:
{code}/rest/api/1.0/projects/<projectKey>/repos/<repositorySlug>/pull-requests/<pullRequestId>/comments{code}

Rationale:
It is inconvenient to have to provide this information for multiple reasons.

1. If I am providing a line number and whether the comment should be attached to the source or destination side of the diff, this is enough information to determine whether the line was removed/added/context.

2. If I specify that this is a context line, then the line number is always interpreted as being in the source file. Commenting on a context line in the destination requires enumerating all hunks, and all segments within each hunk, to correctly map the destination line number to the source line number.
fields.summary: Remove the "lineType" requirement from the REST API call to add line comments to pull requests

fields.description:
Currently comments can only be added within 10 lines of a change.  This restriction should be removed.

Example use case:
"Consider a change to a macro in a header which introduces a bug at the site of the expansion of that macro in a different source file. Even though the source file was not modified by any commit, I still would like to be able to comment on how a bug has been introduced at that point."
fields.summary: Remove the placement restriction on inline comments

fields.description:
h4. Summary
User unable to switch between file at Bitbucket Server Pull request's diff tab when a particular file contains "%" character/s

h4. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a file with name {{%fooname%.classfile}}.
# Made a few changes to the file and commits for each changes to make Pull Request.
# Created a pull request which involves the file.
# Navigate to {{Diff}} tab of the created pull request.
# Clicked on the {{%fooname%.classfile}} file to view its content.
# Clicked other listed file to view its file content.

h4. Expected Results
The URL should able to navigate from one file to another without any manual alteration, reloading or navigate to different link.

h4. Actual Results.
Unable to navigate to any other file listed in the {{Diff}} tab of the same Pull request.

h4. Workaround
Based on the issue, I able to suggest two different workaround for the file name with {{%}} character:
* When view/opening the file, practice to open with new tab so that you can simply close it. This will reduce time on changing URL manually or visiting another link the revisit back to {{diff}} to different file.
* Every time you have visit the file with {{%}} character, manually edit the URL by simply adding {{25}} on the right of {{%}}. This will allow you to navigate normally but the hassle is that you've to manually type in {{25}} for every single visit to file with {{%}} character.
fields.summary: User unable to switch between file at Bitbucket Server Pull request's diff tab when a particular file contains "%" character/s
